questions.text: While assessing a 33-year-old lady who had been in a road traffic accident, you note watery discharge from her nose mixed with the blood. The nasal discharge has the following appearance on filter paper. Which of the following statements correctly describes the discharge seen in this condition?

choices.text: Straining does not increase the discharge

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of a lady presenting with watery nasal discharge mixed with blood following a road traffic accident and the image showing the characteristic double-target sign, is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea. CSF fluid is has a sugar content of >30 mg/dl.

CSF rhinorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose. It can occur as clear fluid or be mixed with blood, particularly in cases of acute head injuries. Fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause of this. Other causes include accidental or surgical trauma, infection and inflammation of the sinuses, neoplasms, and congenital lesions associated with skull base defects or may occur spontaneously.

When CSF rhinorrhea occurs after head trauma, it often contains a mixture of blood, leading to a characteristic appearance known as the double-target sign when collected on a piece of filter paper. This sign presents as a central red spot (indicating blood) surrounded by a lighter peripheral halo.

CSF fluid gushes down on straining and bending forward. It cannot be sniffed back. CSF doesn’t stiffen a handkerchief, but nasal secretions do because of their mucus content.

High-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak.

Beta-2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CSF rhinorrhea. Beta trace protein is another protein that is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus and is specific to CSF.

Treatment of CSF rhinorrhea:

  • Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in the semi-sitting position.
  • Avoiding blowing of nose, sneezing, and straining.
  • Persistent cases may be treated surgically by intracranial or nasal endoscopic approach.
Feature CSF fluid Nasal secretion
History

Nasal or sinus surgery, Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, head injury, or intracranial tumor

Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, head injury, or itching in the nose, or lacrimation
Flow of discharge

A few drops or a stream of fluid gushes down when bending forward or straining and cannot be sniffed back

 Continuous. No effect on bending forward or straining. Can be sniffed back
Character of discharge

Thin, watery, and clear

Slimy (mucous) or clear (tears)
Sugar content

More than 30 mg/dl

Presence of beta-2 transferrin and beta trace proteins

Always present. It is specific to CSF

  Always absent

 

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, now presents with pain and swelling at the same site. On examination, a discharging sinus is seen. His X-ray image is given below. The discharging sinus forms most frequently when pus spreads through which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of an accident 2 years ago, experiencing symptoms of pain and swelling at the site of injury, with the presence of a discharging sinus and an X-ray of the lower limb revealing sequestrum and involucrum in the tibia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of chronic osteomyelitis. Pus spreads out of the cortex, along Volkmann's canals and settles sub-periosteally, eventually forming a discharging sinus.


Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accidents). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare-up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

In response to the bacteria, the host bone starts an inflammatory reaction that results in bone destruction and the production of inflammatory cells and exudates (pus). Once sufficient pus is formed, it propagates in the following directions:

Along the medullary cavity- Pus causes thrombosis of the venous and arterial medullary vessels as it spreads throughout the medullary cavity. Hence, a portion of the bone loses its blood supply.

Pus leaves the cortex, travels through Volkmann's canals, and settles sub-periosteally. As a result, the periosteum is lifted off the underlying bone, damaging the periosteal blood supply to that area of the bone. This leads to the formation of a sequestrum. Sequestrum develops when a piece of necrotic bone separates from the surrounding healthy bone, serving as a nidus for infection.

The pus beneath the periosteum produces sub-periosteal new bone (periosteal reaction). The periosteum eventually perforates, allowing pus to escape into the muscle or subcutaneous plane, where it can be felt as an abscess. If left untreated, the abscess bursts through the skin, forming a discharging sinus which is fixed to the underlying bone indicating that infection is coming from the bone. 

The involucrum is the dense new sclerotic bone surrounding the sequestrum. It is formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum. Cloacae are the perforations in the involucrum. Pus and tiny spicules of bone may be discharged through them.

The radiograph below shows sequestrum, involucrum and cloacae: 


The epiphyseal plate is resistant to the spread of pus. It may be affected by the inflammatory process at times. The epiphysis-metaphysis junction's capsular attachment keeps pus from entering the nearby joint. In joints with an intra-articular metaphysis, pus can spread to the joint, and cause acute pyogenic arthritis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient who has worked in the gunpowder and explosive manufacturing industry for more than 20 years presents with swelling in the lower jaw. On further examination, multiple discharging sinuses with foul-smelling pus were noted. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a male patient working in the gunpowder and explosive manufacturing industry for more than 20 years, presenting with swelling in the lower jaw and multiple discharging sinuses with foul-smelling pus is suggestive of a phossy jaw, seen in chronic phosphorus poisoning.

Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms, white phosphorus, a highly toxic form, and red phosphorus, the non-toxic form. 

Chronic phosphorus poisoning is common among the workers of phosphorus industries, who have had chronic exposure to phosphorus fumes over a period of years. It causes necrosis of the lower jaw in the region of a decayed tooth.

Patients initially present with toothache, followed by swelling of the jaw, loosening of the teeth, necrosis of gums, and sequestration of the bone in the mandible producing considerable facial disfigurement. Phossy jaw is the osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw, with foul-smelling pus discharging multiple sinuses. It is managed surgically and by prevention of further absorption of the poison. 

Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate oxidizes phosphorus into phosphoric acid and phosphates. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb the poison. 

Other options:

Option A - Acute arsenic poisoning resembles bacterial food poisoning. Initially, they have dark-coloured, foul-smelling bloody stools, which later become colourless, odourless, and watery, resembling watery stools of cholera. 

Chronic arsenic poisoning occurs due to accidental ingestion of multiple small doses in food or drinks. In chronic poisoning, finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. The rashes resemble fading measles rash. In prolonged poisoning, a transverse white line, called the Aldrich-Mees line, appears in fingernails. 


Option B: Prolonged ingestion of fluorides results in the mottling of teeth, an increase in the density of bones, lipping of bony margins of vertebrae, which sometimes produce pressure on the spinal cord leading to paraplegia.

Option C: Acute mercury poisoning occurs when elemental mercury vapors produce corrosive bronchitis with fever, chills, and dyspnea. In children, manifestations similar to Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) can be seen. Severe infection can cause loosening of teeth and necrosis of the jaw.

Chronic elemental mercury exposure yields a classic triad of gingivitis, tremors, and neuropsychiatric changes.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with blood-tinged vaginal discharge at 35 weeks of gestation. A positive result was obtained when the vaginal discharge was tested with nitrazine paper. Which of the following components is checked in this test?

choices.text: Exfoliated cells from fetal sebaceous glands

questions.solution:
The nitrazine paper test is used to detect the presence of amniotic fluid in the vaginal discharge as a result of premature rupture of membranes.

The nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH >6. Normal vaginal pH during pregnancy is 4.5–5.5 whereas amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7–7.5. 

False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, and bacterial infections. False-negative test can be seen in the case of scanty amniotic fluid.

The below image shows the nitrazine paper.


Other options:

Option A: Estimation of the volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation in Rh isoimmunisation is done by Kleihauer-Betke test.

Option B: Specific amnionic fluid proteins like alpha microglobulin-1 can be detected by a rapid immunoassay test called AmniSure.

Option D:  Exfoliated fat-containing cells from fetal sebaceous glands turn orange-blue in colour when stained with 0.1% Nile blue sulfate.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with complaints of intermittent discharge from bilateral nipples for the past few months. Mammography findings are given below. The Hadfield operation was carried out because of the involvement of multiple lactiferous ducts. What type of discharge is associated with this condition?

choices.text: Discharge from the surface of the nipple

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a chronic smoker with complaints of intermittent discharge from bilateral nipples for the past few months and mammography showing the characteristic broken needle calcification, is suggestive of duct ectasia which is associated with greenish discharge. 

Duct ectasia is associated with focal dilatation of the lactiferous duct system. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is strongly associated with smoking.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts due to hormonally induced myoepithelial relaxation of the duct wall. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-coloured secretions. The collection may be discharged as shown below.


In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, due to irritation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess, and even mammary duct fistulas. Persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Mammography reveals coarse rod and branching calcifications, described as broken needle calcification. This occurs due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts. If a single duct is involved, then a microdochectomy is performed.

Other options:

Option A: Intraductal papilloma is a benign condition wherein a wart-like growth occurs within the mammary ducts. They are made up of glandular and fibrous tissue and vascular vessels. It is associated with blood-stained discharge.

Option C: Galactorrhea is characterised by the spontaneous release of milky discharge from multiple ducts in both nipples. It may be associated with a prolactin-secreting adenoma of the pituitary gland. Drugs that lead to increased prolactin secretion and galactorrhoea include amitriptyline, metoclopramide and H2 receptor antagonists (cimetidine). 

Option D: Paget’s disease is characterized by nipple erythema and irritation. It is associated with pruritus and may progress to crusting and ulceration. It is associated with discharge from the surface of the nipple and not from within the nipple.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge due to a bacterial infection. When subjecting a fresh sample of the vaginal discharge to 10% KOH, a characteristic fishy odour is seen. Which of the following is not responsible for the formation of fishy odour in the above case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings of foul-smelling vaginal discharge and the presence of the characteristic fishy odour on subjecting the vaginal discharge to 10% KOH (whiff test) are suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. It is associated with the marked decrease in the hydrogen peroxide–producing lactobacillus species that constitute most of the normal vaginal microbiota.

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by Mobiluncus curtisii, Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. This change in vaginal microbiota from Lactobacillus species is associated with an increase in pH. Many females are asymptomatic carriers but the majority complain of malodorous vaginal discharge without itching.  

Amsel's Criteria is helpful in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis when 3 of the following 4 are present :

  • Thin, grayish-white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5.
  • Fishy odor of discharge accentuated by adding 10% KOH-(Whiff test). 
  • Presence of clue cells which are vaginal epithelial cells covered with coccobacilli 

The whiff test is performed by mixing vaginal fluid with a drop of KOH on a microscope slide. Because of its alkaline qualities, KOH causes the vaginal fluid to release volatile amines like trimethylamine, which gives the vaginal fluid its distinctive fishy odour. The amines are products of anaerobic bacterial metabolism. 

Treatment is oral metronidazole 500mg BD for 7 days or oral tinidazole 2g for 3 days. Alternatively, oral clindamycin 300mg BID for 7 days can also be given.

The given images show clue cells on microscopy.

questions.text: A young man presenting with ear discharge was diagnosed with acute mastoiditis, for which he underwent cortical mastoidectomy. However, the patient continued to have persistent ear discharge even after the surgery. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient complaining of persistent ear discharge following a cortical mastoidectomy procedure done for acute mastoiditis points towards the diagnosis of petrositis where the patient will present with the characteristic Gradenigo syndrome. 

Acute mastoiditis is the inflammation of the mucosal lining of the antrum and mastoid air-cell system, which commonly accompanies acute suppurative otitis media. When this infection spreads to the petrous part of the temporal bone, it results in petrositis. It may be associated with chronic middle ear infections like chronic suppurative otitis media, acute coalescent mastoiditis and latent mastoiditis. 

Infection most commonly spreads via the posterosuperior tract which starts in the mastoid and runs behind or above the bony labyrinth to the petrous apex. It can also spread via the anteroinferior tract which starts at the hypotympanum near the eustachian tube and runs around the cochlea to reach the petrous apex. 

Petrositis is indicated when a patient with acute mastoiditis has an adequate cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy but still experiences persistent ear discharge and/or deep-seated pain.

The patient presents with Gradenigo syndrome which is a triad of:

  1. Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media
  2. Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve (VI)  palsy
  3. Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve (V) involvement

The patient may also have a fever, headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity. The involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves results in facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo respectively.

Diagnosis of petrositis is done by a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of the temporal bone shows bony details of the air cells and petrous apex. MRI helps to detect the presence of fluid or pus. 

The CT given below shows apicitis petrosa:


Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Cortical, modified radical or radical mastoidectomy is often required if not already done. It is necessary to identify the fistulous tract, which is then expanded and curetted to allow for unrestricted drainage.

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger sign is edema over the mastoid, which is secondary to the thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint dislocation. The patient presents with neck pain and torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. It is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical variants of tinea capitis infection is associated with discharging pus and sinus formation?
questions.solution:
The clinical variant of tinea capitis infection associated with discharging pus and sinus formation is kerion.

Tinea capitis also called ringworm of the scalp is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children. Clinical features of tinea capitis are patchy hair loss, scaling, tender lymphadenopathy, and in severe cases, there might be pustules and crusting of the affected area along with sinus formation. 

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Endothrix - a non-inflammatory type in which multiple black dots are present within the areas of alopecia. It is most commonly caused by T. tonsurans and T. violaceum.

 

  • Ectothrix- a mild inflammatory type in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen. Microsporum audouinii, M.canis, M.equinnum, and M.ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.
  • Kerion -a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair. It is associated with sinus formation and visible pus discharge from follicles. It is commonly caused by T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.

 

  • Favus - is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. It is caused by T. schoenleinii


Treatment:

  • Terbinafine: <10 Kg- 62.5 mg; 10-20 kg - 125 mg; >20 kg- 250 mg, all given daily for 4 weeks.
  • Itraconazole: 2-4 mg/kg/day for 4-6 weeks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who serves in the military presents with swelling in the natal cleft with occasional purulent discharge from it. On examination, a single point of discharge is seen. Per rectal examination has no significant findings. Which of the following components is strongly associated with the etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a military personnel with swelling in the natal cleft associated with pain and discharge is suggestive of pilonidal sinus disease. Broken hair is most commonly associated with the etiology of this condition.

Pilonidal sinus disease is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty. Drivers and hairdressers are more commonly affected.

The pilonidal sinus opening is seen usually in the midline between the level of the sacrococcygeal joint and the tip of the coccyx. The other sites that they can be affected include the interdigital cleft and axilla.

Pathophysiology:

Buttock friction and shearing forces in this area allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can also form and are lined with granulation tissue and discharge. 

Clinical features:

  • Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine.
  • A foreign-body-type reaction may then lead to the formation of an abscess.
  • Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

Treatment

  • Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.
  • Abscess:
    • Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair.
  • Surgical techniques: Bascom’s, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease.

Other options :

Options A - Hidradenitis suppurativa refers to follicular occlusion, folliculitis and secondary infection with skin flora. This leads to chronic suppurative, painful, skin abscesses, sinus tracts, and scarring. It usually occurs in skin containing apocrine glands, like the axillae and groins. They are usually found in the perineum while pilonidal sinus is found in the natal cleft. 

The following image shows a hidradenitis suppurativa lesion with multiple boils and points of discharge.


Option C - Anal fistula is an abnormal communication, that runs outwards from the anorectal lumen to an external opening on the skin of the perineum or buttocks. It presents with bloody discharge and in some cases feces in the sinus tract while a pilonidal abscess/sinus does not. The internal opening is usually palpated as a point of induration in rectal examination.

Options D - Postanal dermoid is a cystic condition that usually remains asymptomatic until adult life. Hair is not found in the sinus tract. The cyst is easily palpable on rectal examination. Pressure over the sacrococcygeal region with a finger in the rectum may cause a flow of sebaceous material. Given the background of serving in the military, postanal dermoid is less likely to be the answer to this question.

questions.text: A 51-year-old diabetic male patient presented with a painful hard lump with purulent discharge from multiple follicular orifices as seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a diabetic male patient presenting with a painful hard red lump with purulent discharge from multiple follicular orifices is suggestive of carbuncle.

A carbuncle is a deep infection of a contiguous group of follicles accompanied by inflammation of surrounding connective tissue. The causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus. It is commonly associated with diabetes mellitus. 

It presents as a painful hard lump in the initial stage of infection which increases in size to about 3-10 cm. This is followed by suppuration and pus is discharged from multiple follicular orifices.

Most lesions are usually solitary and are present on the back of the neck, the shoulders or the hips and thighs.

Microbiological swabs are taken from the lesion for the culture of the organisms present. Treatment with penicillinase-resistant antibiotics such as flucloxacillin is recommended. Incision and drainage or saucerisation may be required to aid the removal of pus and necrotic tissue. Lesions usually heal with scarring. 

Other options:

Option A: Folliculitis is infection and inflammation of the follicular ostium. It presents as small follicular papules or pinhead pustules which are rarely painful. They heal without scar formation.

The image below shows a picture of folliculitis:


Option B: Ecthyma is a pyogenic skin infection marked by the formation of adherent crusts beneath which ulceration occurs. It is mainly caused by Group A Streptococcus like S. pyogenes, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and S. aureus. 

On an erythematous base, small bullae or pustules are quickly covered in a hard crust of dried exudate that has an indurated base and grows larger by peripheral accretion. The crust, when removed reveals an irregular, purulent ulcer.

Option D: Furuncle or boil is an abscess of the hair follicle (usually vellus type). It presents as a small inflammatory nodule that soon becomes pustular and necrotic and eventually heals to leave a violaceous macule and a permanent scar following the discharge of a necrotic core. 

The image below shows a furuncle:

questions.text: The presence of thin, brown, sweet-smelling discharge from a grossly contaminated wound that is tender on palpation and associated with crepitus, is characteristically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The presence of thin, brown, sweet-smelling discharge from a grossly contaminated wound that is tender on palpation and associated with crepitus is characteristically seen in clostridial myonecrosis/ gas gangrene.

Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridium perfringens. These gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-bearing bacilli are widely found in soil and feces. Patients who are immunocompromised, diabetic, or have a malignant disease are at greater risk, particularly if they have wounds containing necrotic or foreign material, resulting in anaerobic conditions.

The kinetic energy of high-velocity missiles or shrapnel causes extensive tissue damage, making military wounds an ideal environment for clostridial infection.

Gas gangrene wound infections are characterized by severe local wound pain and crepitus (gas in the tissues that can be seen on plain radiographs). The bacteria can be demonstrated in a thin, brown, sweet-smelling exudate produced by the wound. Following the release of collagenase, hyaluronidase and alpha-toxin, edema and spreading gangrene occur.

Nagler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. 


Treatment of gas gangrene:

  • Emergent surgical exploration and thorough debridement are extremely important.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be considered after surgery and antibiotics (penicillin G plus clindamycin; 600–900 mg IV q6–8h), and anti-gas gangrene serum has to be initiated after debridement.

Other options:

Option A: Fournier's gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Clinically, sudden scrotal pain with associated prostration, pallor, and pyrexia can be seen. It is associated with foul-smelling purulent exudate.

Option B: Toxic epidermal necrolysis is the severe form of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) seen in older people. It presents as rashes which develop into large thin blisters which contain anything from thin, sterile cloudy fluid to frank yellow pus underneath. There is involvement of the entire epidermal layer. It is not associated with crepitus.

Option D: Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections are characterised by a bluish-green discharge due to the pigment, pyocyanin produced by the organism. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples.

questions.text: The MRI scan of a farmer who presented with swelling and discharge in his left foot showed the characteristic 'dot-in-a-circle' sign. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young man who presented with swelling in the left foot associated with discharge and an MRI showing the characteristic 'dot-in-a-circle' sign is suggestive of Mycetoma / madura foot caused by Madurella mycetomatis.

MRI shows a small rounded hyperintensity (representing granulation tissue), surrounded by a low signal intensity rim (representing fibrous septa) with a hypointense dot (representing fungal balls or grains) in the centre.


Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, most often affecting the foot or the hand. It can be caused by fungi in which case it is called eumycetoma. Madurella mycetomatis is the most common fungal causative agent. Species of Actinomadura and Nocardia belonging to actinomyces can also cause mycetoma in which case it is referred to as actinomycetoma. Botyromycosis is another form of mycetoma caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources. Within host tissues, the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the colour of which depends on the organism responsible. It results in tumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging these grains or granules.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.
  • Culture samples should also be cultured at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma on the other hand, responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

 The image below shows mycetoma of the foot:


Other options: 

Option A: Trichophyton rubrum is the dermatophytic infection that causes athlete's foot, also known as tinea pedis. It affects the plantar aspect of the foot. Patients present with intertriginous dermatitis of the toes, which is itchy and characterized by fissuring, peeling, and maceration. 

Option B: Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis which is characterised by lesions along the route of lymphatics.


Option C: Fonsecaea pedrosoi causes chromoblastomycosis which is a tropical fungal infection that presents with warty cutaneous nodules (cauliflower-like) on the feet and lower legs. It is commonly seen in barefoot agricultural workers. It is not associated with discharge.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of multiple discharging sinuses for the past 6 months as shown in the image below. Parents say the lesions started as bluish swellings that ulcerated later. Mantoux test showed an induration measuring 30 mm at 72 hours. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 6-year-old child, with a history of multiple discharging sinuses for the past 6 months which started as a bluish swelling that ulcerated to form the multiple swellings and sinuses as shown in the image above and with a positive Mantoux test, is suggestive of scrofuloderma. 

Scrofuloderma is the result of a cutaneous infection adjacent to a tuberculous focus due to direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin. Usually, the lymph nodes, breast, testes, lacrimal gland or duct, infected bone or joint are involved. It commonly occurs in children.

The clinical picture is characterized by asymptomatic, bluish-red subcutaneous, painless, slowly growing nodules that evolve into ulcers and fistulous tracts with drainage of serous, purulent, or caseous content. Fungal tumours can develop from excessive granulation tissue. Sporotrichoid spread can also be seen. The infection site is marked by a distinctive puckered scar after healing.

A skin biopsy taken from the edge of the sinus or ulcer demonstrates the tubercle bacillia and the Mantoux test is usually positive.

Other options

Option A: Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion gradually extend in some areas and heal with scarring in others. Apple jelly nodules are demonstrated on diascopy.


Option C: Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of tuberculid. It occurs due to hypersensitivity to the active tubercular infection. They appear as closely grouped lichenoid papules. The lesions are usually skin colored and are often perifollicular. The papule may have an adherent crust or small pustule.


Option D: Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is caused by exogenous inoculation of M. tuberculosis into the skin through open wounds or abrasions. Lesions appear at the site of inoculation. They appear as verrucous plaque which extends with a serpiginous outline with finger‐like projections. The centre of the lesion may have a white atrophic scar.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought to the OPD with complaints of decreased response to noise stimulus and persistent nasal discharge. On examination, a saddle nose and notched upper central incisors were observed. Ocular examination revealed interstitial keratitis. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, a history of decreased response to noise stimulus (sensorineural hearing loss), notched upper central incisors(Hutchinson teeth) on examination, and interstitial keratitis on ocular examination is suggestive of Hutchinson's triad of congenital syphilis. Hennebert sign is seen in congenital syphilis.

A false-positive fistula test (i.e. positive fistula test without the presence of a fistula) is seen in congenital syphilis and in about 25% of cases of Méniére’s disease and is called the Hennebert sign. In congenital syphilis, it is due to hypermobile stapes on inflammatory fibrous bands between the stapes footplate and saccule or utricle, while in Méniére’s disease, it is due to a distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Other options

Option A-Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal (supplied by the VII cranial nerve) is known as the Hitzelberger sign. It is due to the involvement of the VII cranial nerve in acoustic neuroma.

Option C-A pink or reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane is called the Schwartz sign. It is seen in active otosclerosis.

Option D-The gurgling sound produced on pressing the swelling in the laryngocele is known as Bryce's sign.

Related Pearl: Hutchinson’s Triad

Hutchinson’s triad is a triad of stigmata seen characteristically in congenital syphilis.

Components are as follows:

  • Hutchinson's teeth
  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Sensorineural deafness (not conductive deafness)

questions.text: As a physician in a Suraksha clinic, you will issue the grey kit to patients with all of the following except those with:
questions.solution:
The given Kit-1 (Grey) is not given to patients with vaginal discharge.  

Kit-2 (green) is prescribed to patients with vaginal discharge.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A young woman comes to the Suraksha clinic of the local primary health center. She is examined and the yellow kit is prescribed to her as treatment. Which of the following symptoms did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
Lower abdominal pain is the most likely presenting symptom in the patient. 

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) has started the Suraksha clinic to deal with sexually transmitted infections (STI) and reproductive tract infections (RTI). Pre-packed STI/RTI color-coded kits are supplied through STI/RTI clinics free of cost. The kits are obtained centrally and then supplied to all state AIDS control societies. 

Kit Syndrome/s

Kit 1
(Grey)

Urethral discharge

Cervical discharge

Painful scrotal swelling
Kit 2 (Green) Vaginal discharge / Vaginitis
Kit 3 (White) Non-herpetic genital ulcers

Kit 4
(Blue)

Non-herpetic genital ulcers if allergic to penicillin

Kit 5
(Red)

 Herpetic genital ulcers
Kit 6 (Yellow) Lower abdominal pain

Kit 7
(Black)

 Inguinal bubo

Kit 8

(Brown)

 Anorectal discharge syndrome

Other symptoms seen in the patients prescribed with the yellow kit are: 

  • Fever
  • Vaginal Discharge
  • Menstrual irregularities (heavy, irregular vaginal bleeding)
  • Dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, dysuria and tenesmus
  • Lower backache
  • Cervical motion tenderness

The kit contains cefixime 400 mg tablet to have immediately, metronidazole 400 mg tablet, and doxycycline 100 mg tablet to have twice a day for 14 days. Along with this, the male partner should be treated with kit 1. 

Lower abdominal pain should be followed up on the 3rd, 7rd, and 14th day and a referral should be made if symptoms persist. 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman complains of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A giemsa-stained smear of the discharge is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows Trichomonas vaginalis and infection causes a frothy, greenish-yellow discharge. Curdy white discharge is seen in vaginal candidiasis.

Trichomonas is a protozoan that’s slightly larger than a leucocyte with four anterior flagella and a single posterior flagellum. It exhibits jerky or twitching motility.

Infection of the female genital tract causes the following symptoms:

  • Foul-smelling, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge per vaginum
  • Itching around the vulva
  • Dysuria and frequent micturition

The vagina looks red and inflamed. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

The condition is treated with a single 2 gm dose of metronidazole or tinidazole. The partner must also be treated simultaneously.

questions.text: A lady on oral contraceptive pills presented with white discharge per vaginum. It is not associated with itching or foul smell and stains her underwear yellow in color. Examination of the discharge revealed normal lactobacilli and acidic pH. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of vaginal discharge with no itching and foul smell along with normal lactobacilli count with acidic pH is suggestive of normal vaginal discharge.

Leucorrhea is defined as an excessive normal vaginal discharge.

The term leucorrhea should fulfil the following criteria:

  • The excess secretion is evident from persistent vulval moistness or staining of the undergarments (brownish yellow on drying) or need to wear a vulval pad.
  • It is nonpurulent and nonoffensive.
  • It is nonirritant and never causes pruritus.

The physiologic basis involved in normal vaginal secretion is dependent on the endogenous estrogen level. With the rising estrogen level, there is abundant secretory activity of the endocervical glands and the superficial vaginal epithelium becomes rich in glycogen 

The normal secretion is expected to increase in conditions when the estrogen levels become high. Such conditions are :

  • During puberty—Increased levels of endogenous estrogen lead to marked overgrowth of the endo- cervical epithelium which may encroach onto the ectocervix producing congenital ectopy (erosion) → increased secretion.
  • During menstrual cycle
    • Around ovulation-Peak rise of estrogen → increase in secretory activity of the cervical glands.
    • Premenstrual pelvic congestion and increased mucus secretion from the hypertrophied endometrial glands. 
  • Pregnancy-There is hyperestrinism with increased vascularity. This leads to increased vaginal transudate and cervical gland secretion.
  • During sexual excitement, when there is an abundant secretion from the Bartholin’s glands.

Other options:

Vaginal candidiasis: This condition generally presents with itching and a white, "cottage cheese"-like discharge. The absence of itching and the nature of the discharge described in the scenario rule out this option.

Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is characterized by a thin, gray, foul-smelling discharge. The fact that the discharge in this case does not have a foul smell rules out this option.

Chlamydial infection: Chlamydia infections can cause a range of symptoms, including abnormal vaginal discharge. However, many individuals with Chlamydia are asymptomatic, and the discharge associated with this condition does not typically stain underwear yellow.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above image shows gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes in a stained smear from the urethral discharge sample, which is seen in infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

According to CDC recommendations 2021, the first line of treatment in uncomplicated gonococcal infections is a single dose of ceftriaxone 500 mg IM.

Note: BASHH (British Association for Sexual Health and HIV) in the United Kingdom also recommends higher doses of ceftriaxone of about 500 mg along with azithromycin because it would result in fewer failures.

questions.text: What would be the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
questions.solution:
The average duration of lochial discharge in a postpartum woman is about 24-36 days. The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL.
